author: .paulharris
content: I also had questions from a staking group about whether there was likely to be documentation on how the parital withdrawals contract etc works so they can make use of it, if anyone knows where that may be?

author: .fjl
content: The docs are kind of in the EIP

author: .fjl
content: I have added a little Solidity snippet in the EIP that shows how to use it: https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-7002#fee-overpayment

author: .fjl
content: But please note that this should probably be extended in prod code to guard against high fees

author: .fjl
content: The audit of the system contract noted that the fee updates only once per block, which may lead to some pretty radical fee swings

author: .fjl
content: I actually still think this issue is a serious one

author: .fjl
content: Talked about this with <@543900561460822016> a while ago, and he said that we could change the contract to recompute the fee after adding each request, but it would cost more gas.

author: .fjl
content: the 'excess' is only computed once per block

author: m.kalinin
content: this is true, a gas limit of a block would be the limitation on how much the fee can go up after processing a block

author: m.kalinin
content: i think this is fine as long as we can keep up to a few thousands requests in the queue, it doesn't sound like a good UX though, but i don't know if updating fee per each transaction can improve it much considering the case with a ton of requests in one transaction
